text: So it's kind of a case study for us. But I'm also going to talk about some much, much weirder things. If anybody's interested in the primary papers, the data sets, the software, everything is here. And then here's where I keep my own kind of personal thoughts about what it all means. So I want to start off by just reminding ourselves of something that happened over history is that prior to having a solid theory of electromagnetism, we had static electricity and we had lightning, and we had magnets and we had light. And we all thought those were different things, okay? We thought these were, these were completely different kinds of, kinds of phenomena. And we were also unaware that we actually were only sensitive to a tiny part of this spectrum. What a good theory of electromagnetism did for us is several things.
primary_topics: Historical understanding of electricity and magnetism
content_summary: The speaker discusses the historical understanding of electricity and magnetism, highlighting how they were initially perceived as separate phenomena. The speaker also mentions the limited sensitivity humans have to the electromagnetic spectrum and the importance of a solid theory of electromagnetism.
